ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Question 3 - - I found the assignments quite unhelpful. All of the assignments with the exception of the midterm were group work and on topics determined by the professor. While we could choose within those topics what to focus on, there was really no room to allow our own interests or areas of research in to the class. While I would not want every assignment to be of my own devising and independent, it was hard to sustain real interest and commitment when the assignments were not related to my own interests. I think at least one or two of the assignments should be much more open-ended, to involve applying the concepts learned in class to topics of our choosing. Also, all of the group work, though interesting, adds extra work to any assignment, and I felt that the coordination needed every time detracted from how much I could learn from and dive into each assignment.Question 7 - - I really thought I would've given Cashore a much better over all grade than this. When he's on and prepared, he's fantastic. For this class, however, he was absent, absent-minded, distracted, and did not seem to have a sort of long-range view for the class to carry us through. He was gone for presentations, guest speakers, our in class mock negotiations (two days), for a week in February, and for various other classes. The semester thus felt disjointed and without the expert guidance that he could have offered.
This course could have been fantastic but there were two key problems: (1) the professor missed way too many classes and (2) the assignments felt very disjointed from the lecture material.

I would suggest to try to improve coordination between the TA and the instructor, some times there was a feeling of them having not discussed the assignments, class logistics, grading or even work between both TA's.

Question 1: Readings were well done.Question 2: Professor generally gave good lectures but was always asking for reminders on the time. If you are at this level of teaching, you should be able to plan a lecture such that you don't have to interrupt it multiple times to solicit the hour.Question 3: I've never encountered a collection of class assignments that better represented "busy work." There was absolutely no learning value-add for me in completing these assignments. At a graduate level, we should not have to have our time filled with meaningless assignments of the sort tacked on to this class. THey also took a lot of time to do and do well. None of us had a sufficient background to come up with a panacea solution for the environmental problems randomly assigned (fisheries, extractive industries, etc.). I would have rather listened to the instructor discussing this than my classmates. Again, no learning value and shifting the burden of teaching onto others.It seems there was also a disconnect between many of the assignments having to do with Rio but then Rio was not really addressed in the class. Further, we received a list at the beginning of the term detailing all of the assignments. One assignment - a two day simulation - was never listed on this document. Shortly before the exercise, we receive a set of assignments related to it including needing to write a position paper, opening speech, etc. This came just before finals and it was inconvenient for many who were already working on assignments that had been made known in advance. Not considerate of our time and demonstrated the fact that the TAs and instructor were not communicating or invested in planning this class.Question 4: Yes, heavier because the assignments just took so long to complete.Question 7: My "poor" rating is based first and foremost on the fact that at least six classes were canceled over the course of the semester. For a week and a half class did not even meet because the professor was attending conferences. I understand that there are many research demands outside of the classroom, however, I am not paying full tuition for this kind of absent teaching style. At one point, I heard that Sebastien (the TA) justified this as being a midterm recess because the class was cross-listed. Every student in that class - save two undergrads - were in FES. That logic, therefore, makes no sense to me.After this lack of continuity, which really disrupted my ability to keep the class material fresh in my mind, he was then virtually absent in that half of the rest of the classes were student-led, and then the two days of simulation he did not even show up to. I understand that these were meant to be led by the TA's, but given his , I found this quite insulting.Further, the professor was totally disconnected from the management of the class in terms of assignment planning. He wasunwilling to really compromise when it was pointed out that one assignment came totally out of the blue during the week before finals. Clearly, the TAs were not communicating on planning their respective assignments, and this was a time when he should have stepped in and made sure that everything matched the syllabus, as it was related to students at the beginning of the term.

The structure of the class is good but I think the readings are a bit too much. Class twice per week with 3-5 readings for every class is a lot.Although the assignments were all very interesting and fun they were also a bit too many - I am talking about the addition of the negotiation at the end.

7. Cashore was great, very entertaining and illustrated complex points with helpful anicdotes. Each lecture covered a lot of ground, but there was not much discussion.1. The readings were rarely refrenced and not super helpful creating a disincentive to read them at all.3, 7.b. and 9 - The TAs were disinterested, did not seem to read our work, and treated the class like children; this was a problem because they were primarily the ones giving assignments, grading and structuring class activities.The class would be so much better if Cashore was more activly running class or had better TAs.

Although the class was excellent, the professor was not present during whole weeks. These classes would then be made up by extra hours but many times would interfere with other classes.Assignments for this class and their rubrics should be clearly stated from the start.

The lectures that Cashore knew well and had prepared. His sense of humor and refreshing politics. Some really thought-provoking concepts and ways of looking at the world, especially when it comes to perspectives that are not only based on economic arguments.
The lectures and the readings. The reading list was great and Professor Cashore is a great lecturer.
I learned more in this class than I have in entire semesters of four classes.

The best thing about this course was the simulation of the Rio+20 special meeting. This exercise allowed us to have practice on the course material. Another highlight was the student policy proposal presentation. Furthermore the attendance to the Rio+20 conference will be a highlight for the class, because we worked long ways in other related events and the actual debates we had in class were about this conference.
The professor's open-mindedness and engagement with the backgrounds of the students.
Angel Hsu. She was great!
Ben's teaching. He is very animated and really listens to student feedback.
A lot of independent work: a mocking UN negotiation session, presentations on the topic of choice, etc.
Some of the readings were good.
Professor Cashore is great! He is very engaging and thought provocative. The two main books for this course were very appropriate and and excellent reference for this and many other courses.
Cashore's lectures were very informative and intersting.
Having the opportunity to know new philosophy theories of international relations.
materials and theoretical engagement

Teaching us to a framework for thinking about and analyzing policy problems and governance at the international level. The introduction to different international relations theories and worldviews was also very valuable. The instructor makes every class a enjoyable and a tremendous learning experience.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: As mentioned above, the assignments could really use some revision. In addition, the readings were often not referred to in lecture, making the connections harder for a first time policy student to make. This was introduced as an overview course, but a lot of prior knowledge was assumed.In particular, the mock negotiation was poorly run. It was frustrating for this to be the case, given the amount of work (and last minute, too) that we had to put in to prepare.

It is important that there be more coordination between the assignments and the course theme. All of the assigments were focused on Rio+20 but it seemed like we hardly talked about it in class. It would have been helpful to have more formal instruction on the upcoming conference to prepare us for the assingments. Also there were too many assignments at the very end. I would like to see the assingments allow for more independent research and creativity. It would be great for example to be able to write a short research paper on a topic of your choice rather than have to analyze the zero draft. Also, there was generally a lack of clarity in terms of expectations for assignments. Finally, I would completely eliminate the group presentations from the course. As students listening to the presentations we did not get anything from it. It would be MUCH better for the professor to lecture than to have students present on topics they know nothing about. We did not have enough preparation to prepare policy solutions of any interest. If you are still going to incorporate presentations into the class they should be consolidated during one week so as to avoid taking the space of so many possible lectures.
The coordination between readings, the classes V2 resources folder, the syllabus, the assignments and the actual deliverance of the instructor.
The lecture slides could have been a little more clarified and clear-cut.
Getting grades on time to the students.

The class got disconnected in the middle of the semester with several cancelled classes. There were too many small assignments to keep track of, without emphasis of which ones were really important. The Rio+20 stuff was kind of thrown in there and distracted from the overall coherence of the class. Fewer assignments that are more targeted would have been better.
The assignments need to be worthwhile and tied to the readings and lectures in a substantive way.The teaching focused heavily on markets-based solutions. Need a broader perspective.
Balancing the number of readings per class. Balancing the number of assignments.

The assignments need improvement.The policy memo was an ok assignment, but pretty disconnected from the class.The paper prompt was very dull. It felt like an early undergrad or highschool assignment.The exam format was fun, but a lot of other students stressed out and pre-wrote their answers since they were given the questions ahead of time; I guess this works.
Presence of the professor and clear statements on how to right papers.

Sometimes the course was disjointed so ensuring cohesiveness would add a lot to the course. More incorporation of the reading in to the class would also be beneficial. As well, thinking about the time constraints of the class might prove fruitful as we were often scrambling to fit all the material in during a given class.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: The TA was not particularly helpful and did not always respond to requests.

We had two TA's, one of which joined the course midway in the semester. They were helpful when we needed guidance for assignments and by putting their time in organizing the trip to the Rio+20 conference.
The TA's were generally available, especially over email (with quick responses).
When is very busy but always made time for office hours, and gave all the time that was needed when I came in. I didn't really talk to the TA about the class other than administrative questions.
They were both very helpful.

TA's, especially Sebastien, found requests like adding the recommended readings to Classes V2 to be beyond their job description.I'd like to emphasize again that I did not get my graded midterm until after the finals period. I've never seen such a small class require two TAs, and certainly would not have expected it to take this long to grade a midterm. In my mind, this is totally unacceptable.

I contacted Ben a few times and he is very hard to get a hold of but once he acknowledges you he is very attentive and helpful. Ben is even willing to skype with students and this is very cool. Although a few of the office hours were cancelled Ben rescheduled them and even extended them.Sebastien and Angel were always available and very responsive. Thank you guys.
TAs were condacending and provided poor feedback, so I ended up going to Cashore's office hours which were busy, but very helpful and interesting.
It was great. The availability and quality was amazing.
excellent. Both instructor and TAs made themselves available and took the time to explain material with care and passion for the subject matter.
Excellent. Requested help many times from the instructor and TA and both were readily available and provided very useful guidance.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: This course is related in my MEM experience to the understanding of the international governance in environmental policies to then apply this international knowledge into my main interest, which is to understand the interface between the international and national policies in the environment, development and poverty alleviation.
It's a good examination of the area I want to go in; a necessary take on the governance issue.
I am interested in policy issues, and I thought this would be a useful course.
It is directly related to my interest in bridging science sector with policy making processes. The course provided enough examples to clarify difficulties associated with this step.

This class was the perfect fit to my education at FES considering I will be attending the Rio conference as part of my research. The teachings here were also very helpful for my future career plans in regional governance of Latin America.

I thought this course would fit into my studies in environmental policy, and while the lectures provided helpful lessons from political science, the Rio+20 theme didn't seem to workso well). I was poli-sci in undergrad and all of my classes were more advanced than this one.
It gave me a very good picture on how international governance is done and how this can be linked to regional contexts.
Excellent for someone interested in public policy, and environmental policy problem solving at the international scale.
This is my first exposure to international environmental governance and I see it fitting in as to how the international agenda and governance can link to local and regional level action.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to take a course on environmental policy, since the last time I really studied it was in high school.

I took it because I was looking forward to take a class with Ben Cashore and also because the course fits into my interest and curriculum in the MEM experience. He was away during the Fall2011 semester and the foundation class he teaches was not offered, so that was another incentive to take this class, since I couldn't take the other.
The title of the course suggested its alignment with my concentration.
I am interested in policy issues, and I thought this would be a useful course. I had also heard positive reviews of Ben's teaching.
To strengthen my knowledge on policy sector.
Interested in the topic.
To learn more about the history and process of international policy making in the environmental arena. Also, to learn the theory and background behind the Rio+20 negotiations happening this summer.
Cashore seemed really intersting and knowledgable when I shopped that class--it sounded like just the kind of thing I am interested in.
This course was amazing in great part because Ben Cashore is great explaining.
To get a better understanding of the international sphere and because of my interest in Rio+20.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Not really. I had thought that Cashore would be a much more attentive professor, but I still feel like he barely knows the class. The course material and assignments were more focused on Rio+20 than I had realized they would be.
No

I loved the practical exercises, but I have a conflicting feeling with the assignments. The way the policy memo and the midterm paper were graded against the instructions of the assignment itself was a little confusing and thus the feeling of accomplishment didn't came for this assignments. The
Yes.
Unfortunately, no.

Yes and no. I think there were some things about the structure of the class that made it difficult to stay fully engaged sometimes, and have a coherence to what we were learning. Overall I thought the materials and teaching was good, but the class could have been better organized.
Yes.
Not really.
Yes! Good background and framework generation in the first few classes followed by case studies, class exercises and group projects. This class had everything.
not really, Cashore was very entertaining and interesting, but the assignemnts, readings, discussion, and TAs were not as good as I expected.
yes
Yes, the course exceeded my expectations.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: I didn't know what to expect.
I would have gotten more out of the class had the professor not missed so many classes. It should not be allowed to miss and/or reschedule so many classes during one semester.
This course delivered my expectations.
Yes
Yes.
Somewhat.
Yes.
Not as much as I hoped :-(In my opinion, the amount of readings was over whelming and I could not do all for every class. I feel that readings are key for strengthening the class material.
Not really, I expected to learn more and a deeper engagment with the theory and material. Listening to a great lecture is one thing, but not everthing.
yes
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The advantages were getting to know people, various perspectives incorporated, accountability, challenge. The disadvantages were the amount of extra time it takes to coordinate schedules and thoughts and documents.
I don't think there were any advantages and it might be better to make at least one of the assignments an individual assignment.
I always prefer team work to foster discussion on the issues.
The disadvantage was it was somewhat hasty. The advantage was that the parameters were flexible and creativity was encouraged.

The groupwork was okay. Like any group assignment, it takes more effort to try to coordinate scheduled and separate work accordingly. Overall I didn't think we needed 2 group assignments, and overall it started to feel like busywork.

Frequently I had problems with disinterest of other students towards the project. As a result the disadvantage was associated with the grade received for the group project affecting our individual grades, despite the unequal contribution by members. Considering adding team member evaluations in the future can be a major improvement.
Randomly assigned groups and topics. Fine working together but no value-add.
Advantages - feedback, editing, idea generation (depending on your partner).Disadvantages - communication can be sometimes vague, you can be either too agreeable or completely the opposite.

Group work was ok. It was good to talk about policy ideas, but we never really talked about ideas from the course, mostly because none of my group partners seemed to do any of the reading (no incentive to). At times group work was awkward and much more effort than doing it alone.
Having the opportunity of sharing points of views and knowing other positions.
quality of group work varies by group partners - can negatively impact ones grade.

Many smaller assignments made thoroughly delving in to any one topic difficult, especially when trying to deal with getting a new group on the same page constantly. Group work provided very valuable insights and alternative perspectives, however.
Better idea sharing and complimentary skills.No perceived disadvantages

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Maybe Cashore is more available in office hours? A lot of the learning will be on your own, but the lectures that Cashore himself gives will be fantastic.
I would not necessarily recommend taking this course unless the structure is changed. As of now it is too much work for too little content.
The course workload is higher that advertised in the syllabus.
I'd say be sure to keep up with the readings as you go along.
Pray that Angel Hsu is the primary TA.

I think the class is worth taking, but you should come in with some sort of background in international relations, political science, governance etc. I think it's hard to teach a class about this topic when the backgrounds vary widely. You will get a lot more out of it if you already have some background
Take it only if the assignments and quality of teaching improve.

Think out side of the box and be thought provocative. Dont just recite what you have read and agree with everything but try to come up with new (possibly radical/fun) ideas. This is your chance to come up with something wild that could possibly be an awesome idea but if not it is just a class.I wish I did this; my policy proposal adhered to the boundaries of whats already 'acceptable' ie- int negotiations, regimes, regional cooperation etc :-(

Go to Cashore's office hours. He is great fun and very helpful.It seems the TAs primarily read and grade work, so get to know the TAs.You will be fine skimming the readings; the articles are generally beter then the main books assigned, except for Speth's, which is great, but should be brought up inclass more.
Read. Ask the TAs to be very clear on how will the papers be graded.
read ahead of time. Ask lots of questions.
Read the books, know the worldviews, and come to class!
Provides a good overview and academic structure of policy and governance in environmental issues however it does not provide a deeper analysis of current environmental diplomacy and negotiations
